conclusion: Understanding the setup of the problem with two balls attached to a light rod rotating in a vertical plane.
The rod is light, meaning its mass is negligible compared to the masses of the balls.
The rod rotates in a vertical plane around point O, which is L from ball A and 2L from ball B.
At the highest point of ball A, it exerts no force on the rod.
Ball A is only under the influence of gravity at the highest point.
Both balls move in circular paths with radii L and 2L, respectively, with the same angular velocity ω.
At the highest point, the centripetal force required for ball A is provided by its weight: mg = mω²L.
Solving for ω gives ω = sqrt(g/L).
Ball B is at the bottom of its circular path at the same instant.
Forces on ball B: weight (mg upward) and rod force (F_B).
Centripetal force for ball B is F_c = mω²(2L).
Net force on ball B: F_net = F_B + mg = mω²(2L).
Substituting ω = sqrt(g/L) into the equation gives F_net = 2mg.
Solving for F_B gives F_B = mg.
Force exerted by ball B on the rod is mg downward due to Newton's third law.
Reconsidering direction: rod exerts force upward on ball B, so ball B exerts force downward on the rod.
Rechecking: At the highest point of ball A, only gravity provides centripetal force: mg = mω²L.
Reconfirming ω = sqrt(g/L).
Considering energy conservation: maximum kinetic energy at lowest point of ball A.
Considering energy conservation: minimum kinetic energy at highest point of ball A.
